facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 177 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 177 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 28, 195

facts.text: Nagpur High Court judgment and decree dated September 28, 1953 in First Appeal No. 115 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 28, 1953, of the former Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 115 of 1951, arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 25, 1951,

facts.text: Additional District Judge, Bhandara judgment dated July 25, 1951 in Civil Suit No. 14-A of 1957 dismissing the plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 25, 1951, of the Court of Additional District Judge, Bhandara, in Civil Suit No. 14-A of 1957.

facts.text: Suit brought by Mst. Chaltibai, widow of Lakshminarayan, against Badrinarayan (defendant No. 1) and Kishori Lal (defendant No. 2).

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was brought by Mst. Chaltibai, the widow of Lakshminarayan, a Marwari Aggarwal of the District of Bhandara against Badrinarayan defendant No. 1 and his son Kishori Lal defendant No. 2 number appellant

facts.text: Properties in sch. B and C belonged to Chaltibai as heir to Lakshminarayan; possession of property in schedule D sought.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that properties in sch. B C belonged to her as heir to her deceased husband Lakshminarayan and for possession of the property in schedule D.

facts.text: Badrinarayan and Lakshminarayan were brothers; Badrinarayan elder carried business at Raipur; Lakshminarayan younger at ancestral village Tirora.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the litigation relevant for the purpose of this judgment are these Badrinarayan and Lakshminarayan were two brothers the former who was elder was carrying on business at Raipur and the latter who was younger carried on business in the ancestral village named Tirora

facts.text: Lakshminarayan's first wife died in 1919 leaving a son and a daughter.

anchor.surface_text: where it is stated Badrinarayan also was doing some business. Lakshminarayans first wife died in 1919 leaving a son and a daughter.

facts.text: Lakshminarayan married respondent Mst. Chaltibai in 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In 1922 Lakshminarayan married the respondent Mst. Chaltibai.

facts.text: Lakshminarayan's son died sometime after marriage to Chaltibai; only remaining child daughter Mst. Jamnabai married to Chotteylal.

anchor.surface_text: His son died sometime after this marriage and therefore the only remaining child of Lakshminarayan was the daughter Mst. Jamnabai who was married to one Chotteylal.

facts.text: Lakshminarayan died on January 6, 1936 of heart disease; estate in schs. B, C, D valued at about Rs. 30,000.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1936, Lakshminarayan died of a heart disease leaving his estate which is given in schs. B, C and D and is valued at about Rs. 30,000.

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged Lakshminarayan died suddenly without prior heart disease; appellant pleaded heart trouble from 1934 leading to despair of begetting son.

anchor.surface_text: Although the plaintiff Chaltibai, number respondent, had alleged that Lakshminarayan died suddenly and did number suffer from any heart disease previous to his death, the appellant pleaded that Lakshminarayan developed heart trouble in 1934.

facts.text: Appellant claimed adopted by Lakshminarayan in Jyestha (May-June) 1935, aged 13, youngest son of Badrinarayan.

anchor.surface_text: He also pleaded that because of this heart trouble Lakshminarayan became despaired of begetting a son and therefore adopted in Jaisth  May-June  1935 the appellant Kishorilal then aged 13 years who was the youngest of the five sons of his brother Badrinarayan,

facts.text: After adoption, appellant resided with Lakshminarayan, performed obsequies, placed on gaddi, turban tied per caste custom.

anchor.surface_text: He further pleaded that after his adoption he resided with Lakshminarayan as his adopted son and when Lakshminarayan died he performed his obsequies as such adopted son, was placed on the gaddi and the turban was tied on his head in accordance with the custom of the caste

facts.text: On 13th day after death, respondent took appellant in her lap from Badrinarayan with consent of relations.

anchor.surface_text: that he was on the thirteenth day  tervi  taken by the respondent Chaltibai in her lap from Badrinarayan with the companysent and in the presence of the relations of Lakshmi- narayan on the thirteenth day of the death of Lakshminarayan

facts.text: Appellant entered possession of estate and recognized as adopted son by respondent up to 1946; respondent performed appellant's marriage in 1942.

anchor.surface_text: that he entered into possession of the estate of the deceased Lakshminarayan and was recognised as his adopted son even by the respondent who companytinued to accept and treat him as such upto 1946 and in 1942 the respondent performed his  the appellants marriage .

facts.text: Partition in Badrinarayan family on October 30, 1943; appellant received no share due to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: After he attained majority he managed the estate himself and there was a partition in the family of Badrinarayan on October 30, 1943, in which the appellant, because of his having been given out in adoption in another family, received numbershare.

facts.text: Respondent denied adoption and treatment as adopted son; illiterate pardanashin, reposed confidence in Badrinarayan who managed estate.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in the plaint denied both the adoption and the treatment or acceptance of the appellant as an adopted son. She also stated that she was an illiterate purdanashin woman who was number companyversant with the management of business and after the death of her husband she reposed full companyfidence in Badrinarayan

facts.text: Respondent signed papers at Badrinarayan's instance without understanding, sometimes blank.

anchor.surface_text: who assured her that he would properly look after her affairs, business and property and companysequently Badrinarayan took over the management of the estate and the account books and also looked after companyrt work. At his instance she  the respondent  signed certain papers without understanding them

facts.text: Disputes led to proceedings under ss.107/145 CrPC; receiver appointed; Magistrate order dated May 19, 1947 directing civil court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his father Badrinarayan then attempted to oust her from the business and the estate of her husband which led to disputes between the parties and proceedings under ss.107 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure were started, a receiver was appointed and the Magistrate by an order dated May 19, 1947,

facts.text: Appellant in criminal case asserted adoption six months prior to death; respondent denied in plaint.

anchor.surface_text: directed the parties to have their rights decided by a civil companyrt. This order was unsuccessfully challenged by the appellant in revision. In the criminal case the appellant, it is alleged, asserted that he had been adopted by Lakshminarain six months prior to his death, a fact which the respondent Chaltibai denied in her plaint.

facts.text: Trial court held adoption proved but found against estoppel, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit. It held the adoption proved but found against the appellant on the question of estoppel.

facts.text: High Court reversed finding on factum of adoption, held no adoption; allowed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on appeal reversed the finding as to the factum of adoption but upheld the finding on the question of estoppel. ... The appeal was therefore allowed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held factum of adoption not established by Lakshminarayan.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all these facts into companysideration the High Court, in our opinion, has company- rectly held that the factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan has number been established.

facts.text: No estoppel applicable as both parties knew true facts; no misrepresentation.

anchor.surface_text: In this case both the parties were aware of the truth of the facts and companysequently the doctrine of estoppel was inapplicable.

facts.text: No formal deed of adoption; proved by oral evidence of six witnesses including family members.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberformal deed of adoption, the appellant therefore sought to prove it by the evidence of six witnesses who were. his real brother Mohanlal, his natural father Badrinarayan and two relations Narsingdas and Shankarlal,

concepts.interpretation: Evidence must be free from suspicion of fraud, consistent, probable; failure to produce accounts suspicious

issues.text: Did the deceased Lakshminarayan validly adopt the defendant No. 2 in the bright fortnight of Jyestha June , 1935 A. D.?

holdings.text: the High Court, in our opinion, has correctly held that the factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan has not been established.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all these facts into consideration the High Court, in our opinion, has cor- rectly held that the factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan has not been established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of accounts despite commercial community practice, contradictory oral evidence on details and ceremonies, no publicity or invitations, post-adoption conduct inconsistencies like return to natural father and school records listing natural parent.

holdings.text: In this case both the parties were aware of the truth of the facts and consequently the doctrine of estoppel was inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: In this case both the parties were aware of the truth of the facts and consequently the doctrine of estoppel was inapplicable. It cannot be said that the respondent by her own words or conduct wilfully caused the appellant to believe the existence of a certain state of things i.e. adoption by Lakshminarayan and induced him to act on that belief so as to alter his position and therefore she could not be concluded from averring a different state of things as existing at the same time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estoppel requires wilful inducement to believe false facts and alteration of position; inapplicable when both parties know true facts, citing Pickard v. Sear and Mohori Bibi v. Dhurmdas Ghose.

holdings.text: The correct rule of estoppel applicable in the case of adoption is that it does not confer status. It shuts out the mouth of certain persons if they try to deny the adoption, but where both parties are equally conversant with the true state of facts this doctrine has no application.

anchor.surface_text: The correct rule of estoppel applicable in the case of adoption is that it does not confer status. It shuts out the mouth of certain persons if they try to deny the adoption, but where both parties are equally conversant with the true state of facts this doctrine has no application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estoppel prevents denial by certain persons but does not create adoptive status; ineffective between parties knowing true facts.

holdings.text: In our view there is no substance in the plea of estoppel raised by the appellant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents do not admit lifetime adoption by husband; consistent with post-death adoption or no adoption; no alteration based on misrepresentation.

holdings.text: And admissions are not conclusive, and unless they constitute estoppel, the maker is at liberty to prove that they were mistaken or were untrue
holdings.reasoning_summary: Admissions shift onus initially but lose efficacy after full evidence led; rebuttable unless estoppel; both parties knew facts.

holdings.text: As an adoption results in changing the course of succession, depriving wives and daughters of their rights and transferring properties to comparative strangers or more remote relations it is necessary that the evidence to support it should be such that it is free from all suspicion of fraud and so consistent and probable as to leave no occasion for doubting its truth.

anchor.surface_text: As an adoption results in changing the course of succession, depriving wives and daughters of their rights and transferring properties to comparative strangers or more remote relations it is necessary that the evidence to support it should be such that it is free from all suspicion of fraud and so consistent and probable as to leave no occasion for doubting its truth.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High standard of proof required due to impact on succession; applied to reject evidence here.

holdings.text: Failure to produce accounts, in circumstances such as have been proved in the present case, would be a very suspicious circumstance.

anchor.surface_text: Failure to produce accounts, in circumstances such as have been proved in the present case, would be a very suspicious circumstance. The importance of accounts was emphasised by the Privy Council in Sootrugun v. Sabitra.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commercial community maintains detailed accounts; absence corroborates lack of adoption, citing Privy Council.

holdings.text: The mere fact of performance of these funeral rites does not necessarily support an adoption.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Obsequies by juniors possible without adoption; varies by custom; cannot prove factum alone, citing precedents.

holdings.text: Presumptions cannot sustain an adoption even though it might have been acquiesced in by all concerned when as in the present case, the evidence shows that the adoption did not take place.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Conduct and acquiescence create presumption only if factum probable; direct evidence disproves.

anchor.surface_text: The importance of accounts was emphasised by the Privy Council in Sootrugun v. Sabitra 1 in Diwakar Rao v. Chandanlal Rao 2 in Kishorilal v. Chunilal 3 in Lal Kunwar v. Charanji Lal 4 and in Padamlal v. Fakira Debya 5 . The oral evidence of witnesses deposing to the factum of adoption is both insufficient and contradictory.

anchor.surface_text: the Privy Council in Sootrugun v. Sabitra 1 in Diwakar Rao v. Chandanlal Rao 2 in Kishorilal v. Chunilal 3 in Lal Kunwar v. Charanji Lal 4 and in Padamlal v. Fakira Debya 5 . anchor.surface_text: to alter his position and therefore she could not be concluded from averring a different state of things as existing at the same time. See Pickard v. Sear 1 and Square v. Square 2 . The Privy Council in Mohori Bibi v. Dhurmdas Ghogh 3 held that there can be no estoppel where the truth of the matter is known to both the parties. Therefore when both the parties are equally conversant with the true facts the doctrine of estoppel is inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: the fact admitted must be taken to be established Chandra Kunwar v. Narpat Singh 1 . anchor.surface_text: the maker is at liberty to prove that they were mistaken or were untrue Trinidad Asphalt Company v. Coryat 2 . Admissions are mere pieces of evidence and if the truth of the matter is known to both parties the principle stated in Chandra Kunwars case 1 would be inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: with this back. ground that the evidence has to be considered and weighed. anchor.surface_text: not necessarily support an adoption. The performance of these rites frequently varies according to the circumstances of each case and the view and usage of different families. As was pointed out by the Privy Council in Tayamals case 2 the performance of funeral rites will not sustain an adoption unless it clearly appears that the adoption itself was performed under circumstances as would render it perfectly valid.

precedents.cited_proposition: performance of funeral rites does not prove adoption unless adoption itself valid

anchor.surface_text: acts of acquiescence attributed to the respondent but they would be important only if they were brought to bear upon the question which depended upon preponderance of evidence. If the facts are once ascertained, presumption arising from conduct cannot establish a right which the facts themselves disprove See Tayamals case 1 at p. 433. Presumptions cannot sustain an adoption even though it might have been acquiesced in by all concerned when as in the present case, the evidence shows that the adoption did not take place.

precedents.cited_proposition: presumptions or acquiescence cannot establish adoption disproved by evidence

anchor.surface_text: In this case both the parties were aware of the truth of the facts and consequently the doctrine of estoppel was inapplicable. It cannot be said that the respondent by her own words or conduct wilfully caused the appellant to believe the existence of a certain state of things i.e. adoption by Lakshminarayan and induced him to act on that belief so as to alter his position and therefore she could not be concluded from averring a different state of things as existing at the same time.

edges.explanation: h2 holding estoppel inapplicable addresses whether doctrine applies to prevent denial

anchor.surface_text: The correct rule of estoppel applicable in the case of adoption is that it does not confer status. It shuts out the mouth of certain persons if they try to deny the adoption, but where both parties are equally conversant with the true state of facts this doctrine has no application.
Taking all these facts into consideration the High Court, in our opinion, has cor- rectly held that the factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan has not been established.

anchor.surface_text: As an adoption results in changing the course of succession, depriving wives and daughters of their rights and transferring properties to comparative strangers or more remote relations it is necessary that the evidence to support it should be such that it is free from all suspicion of fraud and so consistent and probable as to leave no occasion for doubting its truth.
Taking all these facts into consideration the High Court, in our opinion, has cor- rectly held that the factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan has not been established.
Taking all these facts into consideration the High Court, in our opinion, has cor- rectly held that the factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan has not been established.
